      Visual Arts

      
        
           
          Atlanta Contemporary presents Michi Meko’s exhibition Before We Blast Off: The Journey of Divine Forces. Meko’s visual efforts emanate a strong Southern vibe paying more homage to its urban subcultures than an affinity for rocking chairs. The Alabama-born artist manipulates iconography to embody a new meaning, often, like in this collection, taking on themes of perseverance. His fascination with the relationship between physical and psychological is palpable in his work that blends clear, straightforward images with amorphous scribbling and other shapes. In a way, it kinda makes perfect sense Meko funded his Atlanta move with winnings from a gambling match with a flagrant Alabaman gangster. It’s his mysterious familiarity that draws you in.

          The goofy staging takes on a self-described format akin to a BuzzFeed listicle which … is not a theatrical approach most of us could possibly find trite. Perry Frost, part of the Woodruff Arts Center family and Dad’s Garage’s youngest improviser, penned the piece. Longtime Dad’s player Matt Horgan (who has writing credits for productions such as Song of the Living Dead: A Zombie Musical and Drove, among others, under his belt) directs. The play investigates some of the most catastrophic snafus in modern human history — but don’t expect any heart-shaped gems or unsinkable ships; the website explicitly reads in a parenthetical aside: “Note: There will be NO Titanic. Too easy!” Points for creativity.
